data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.Title
data.value: AdLer input support

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.QualityCheck.Title
data.value: Quality check

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.Info.Text
data.value: In the context of competency-based higher education and the associated shift in perspective from "teaching to learning", learning objectives have also come into focus. Learning objectives are also the most precise description of the desired learning outcomes. Learning outcomes describe what students should know and be able to do at the end of a learning section and what attitudes are expected of them. They are recorded in writing and communicated in a situational manner. The what-whereby-what-for-structure and taxonomy of learning objectives (e.g. according to Anderson/Krathwohl) are helpful in this context, to select appropriate verbs for formulating learning outcomes on the basis of different levels of competence.

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.Button.Create
data.value: Create

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.TaxonomyLevel.NotSpecified
data.value: Not specified

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.TaxonomyLevel
data.value: Taxonomy level

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.TaxonomyLevel.Info
data.value: The formulation of a learning outcome focuses on the description of corresponding abilities, skills or competencies of the intended learning process of the students. These can be assigned to a taxonomy level based on the complexity of the cognitive processes. The definition of a taxonomy level (according to Anderson & Krathwohl) serves to find a suitable verb of visibility in the further processing steps of the learning outcome formulation.

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.Intro
data.value: You will be able to...

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.VerbOfVisibility
data.value: Verb of visibility*

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.VerbOfVisibility.Info
data.value: The learning outcome describes desired behavioral dispositions and which abilities, skills or competencies the students will have developed at the end of the learning process. It therefore describes actions that are formulated with the help of verbs of external visibility. These represent an action on or with an external object. Verbs such as "understand" or "recognize" are therefore not suitable. The verbs of external visibility can be assigned to a taxonomy level.

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.VerbOfVisibility.Placeholder
data.value: Formulate or select

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.VerbOfVisibility.RequiredError
data.value: Specification of the verb is necessary

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.What.RequiredError
data.value: Specification of "What" is necessary

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.What.Placeholder
data.value: Text field

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.What
data.value: What? (Topic)*

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.What.Info
data.value: The "What" states which learning content (content-related topic) is to be addressed as part of the students' competence acquisition. In the following steps, this is further formulated into a corresponding ability, skill or competence with the help of a taxonomy level and a verb of visibility.

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.Whereby.Placeholder
data.value: Text field

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.Whereby.Text
data.value: by...

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.Whereby
data.value: Whereby?

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.Whereby.Info
data.value: The "with what" describes the theoretical or practical tools students use to carry out their actions. These are, for example, formulas, models, plans, concepts, tools, etc., which are taught during the course and whose application is practiced. The use and linking of these tools forms the basis for competent action. A helpful question when formulating this is: "How do students achieve the ability, skill or competence?".

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhatFor.Placeholder
data.value: Text field

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhatFor.Text
data.value: to...

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhatFor.Info
data.value: The "What for" provides an outlook on the purpose for which the learning unit was designed. The focus is not on the exam. Rather, the "What for" illustrates the students' options for action once they have mastered what they have learned. The action or situation of the "what for" often takes place in a more complex environment and under more difficult conditions than in the learning situation. Helpful questions when formulating this are: "For what (concrete and/or long-term) purpose should the competencies be acquired?" and/or "What do students need the acquired skills, abilities or competencies for after the course?".

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhatFor
data.value: What for?

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.Text
data.value: First, think about the taxonomy level at which you want to formulate your learning outcome.

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhatIsConstructiveAlignment.Part1
data.value: Constructive alignment according to Biggs (2011) is a didactic principle that is used particularly in higher education didactics. It aims to align teaching/learning activities and performance assessments with the objectives of teaching/learning units. Teachers plan their courses in such a way that there is a coherent connection between learning objectives, teaching/learning activities and performance assessments.

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhatIsConstructiveAlignment.Text.Image
data.value: The illustration shows the connection between the three components and key questions that teachers should ask themselves when designing the course.

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhatIsConstructiveAlignment.Part3
data.value: This approach creates a cognitive process in which the dimensions of learning outcomes, performance assessment and learning activities are aligned with each other and are therefore coherent. The stronger this alignment is, the greater the potential of the course to promote learning and expand students' skills.

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhatIsConstructiveAlignment.Title
data.value: What is constructive alignment?

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhatAreLearningOutcomes.Title
data.value: What are learning outcomes?

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhatAreLearningOutcomes.Part1
data.value: In the literature, other terms are also used as an alternative to the term learning outcome, such as learning result or the English terms learning output and learning outcome. However, the terms are often used interchangeably, resulting in a labyrinth of terminological confusion. For this reason, the term learning outcome is used consistently in the context of AdLer input support.

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhyLearningOutcomesInTeaching.Title
data.value: Why is the use of learning outcomes in teaching important?

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhyLearningOutcomesInTeaching.Part1
data.value: benefit from the use of constructive alignment. By formulating learning outcomes precisely, they gain clarity about their intentions, which guide their actions when planning, implementing and evaluating teaching. Without clear formulation, many of the teachers' learning outcomes remain unspoken and are therefore difficult to reflect on. As a result, they cannot be used as a teaching design tool, or only to a limited extent. In addition, the use of learning objectives creates the basis for student-centered teaching, as teachers consciously deal with and reflect on the orientation of teaching and the subsequent formulation of learning outcomes.

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhyLearningOutcomesInTeaching.Part2
data.value: can better understand the objectives of a course by using learning outcomes. Learning outcomes can therefore be used as a means of communication to avoid misunderstandings between teachers and students, as the course or teaching unit becomes more transparent and comprehensible. This promotes learning success.

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.QualityCheck.One
data.value: Who is the real protagonist in the plot?

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.QualityCheck.Two
data.value: Is the process of the activity understandable for outsiders?

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.QualityCheck.Three
data.value: Do the verbs describe an action on/with an external learning object?

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.QualityCheck.Four
data.value: Can an audit assignment be formulated from the statement sentence?

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.QualityCheck.Five
data.value: Is the amount of work involved in the learning process proportionate?

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.QualityCheck.Six
data.value: Are the theoretical or practical tools for the action named?

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.QualityCheck.Subtitle
data.value: Reflection questions to check high-quality formulated learning outcomes:

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.QualityCheck.Seven
data.value: Is it clear what purpose the learning unit serves?

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.TabPanelFour

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.Sources
data.value: Sources

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhatAreLearningOutcomes.DescriptionText.Table
data.value: Table: Goal types and training level

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhatIsConstructiveAlignment.DescriptionText.Image
data.value: Figure: Constructive Alignment

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhatIsConstructiveAlignment.Part2
data.value: For teachers, this means that they first formulate learning outcomes when planning their courses and use these as a basis. The corresponding performance assessments are then designed to check whether the competencies have been achieved. The third step is to select the learning activities that best support students on their way to achieving the learning outcomes.

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhatAreLearningOutcomes.Part2
data.value: Learning outcomes describe what students should know and be able to do at the end of a learning stage or learning process and what attitudes are expected of them. Learning outcomes are therefore the most precise description possible of the intended learning results. They are recorded in written form and communicated as appropriate to the situation. Learning outcomes can be assigned to different levels of competence. The classification scheme of the learning outcomes taxonomy can be used for this purpose (see section “What is a learning outcomes taxonomy?”).

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhatAreLearningOutcomes.Part3
data.value: Learning outcomes can also be differentiated according to their degree of concretization and the duration of the training unit (e.g. an entire module or a single teaching unit). As the duration of the training unit decreases, the degree of concretization increases. Or vice versa: the longer the training unit, the higher the degree of abstraction of the learning outcomes. A distinction can be made between indicative, broad and detailed outcomes.

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhyLearningOutcomesInTeaching.Part1.Italic
data.value: Teachers

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhyLearningOutcomesInTeaching.Part2.Italic
data.value: Students

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhyLearningOutcomesInTeaching.Part3
data.value: Learning outcomes usually have a positive effect indirectly: while effective learning time has a direct positive effect on learning success, clearly formulated learning outcomes mean that students use more class time effectively as learning time. In addition, clearly formulated learning outcomes enable students to engage with the learning content in a more targeted manner.

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhyLearningOutcomesInTeaching.Part4
data.value: It is also crucial for student-centered teaching that students accept the defined learning outcomes and actively engage with them. Well-formulated learning outcomes can positively influence student engagement through increased transparency. They serve as a meaningful starting point for students to shape their learning process in an effective and self-directed manner.

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhatIsALearningOutcomeTaxonomy.Title
data.value: What is a learning outcome taxonomy?

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhatIsALearningOutcomeTaxonomy.Info.Text.PartOne
data.value: Learning outcomes can be assigned to different competence levels. The classification scheme of the learning outcomes taxonomy can be used for this purpose. This serves as a methodical tool for formulating learning outcomes and helps teachers to describe learning outcomes in a competence-oriented way.

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhatIsALearningOutcomeTaxonomy.Info.Text.PartTwo
data.value: One of the best-known taxonomies of learning outcomes is Bloom's taxonomy of cognitive learning outcomes (1984), which contains six cognitive process dimensions (also known as learning outcome levels). Anderson and Krathwohl (2001) have further developed Bloom's taxonomy. This further development serves as the basis for AdLer input support and is therefore explained in more detail below.

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.LearningOutcomeTaxonomy.AndersonAndKratwohl.Title
data.value: The learning outcome taxonomy according to Anderson and Krathwohl

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.LearningOutcomeTaxonomy.AndersonAndKratwohl.Part3
data.value: The various taxonomy levels do not have a precisely defined dependency relationship with each other, but dependencies can also occur. For example, a person cannot judge which of two analysis methods is more suitable for a certain process (“Judge” category) without having understood both methods (“Understand”). On the other hand, it is quite possible for someone to apply a procedure (“Apply”) without having fully understood it (“Understand”).

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.LearningOutcomeTaxonomy.AndersonAndKratwohl.Part2
data.value: The following table provides an overview of the different levels of the learning outcome taxonomy according to Anderson and Krathwohl. These are each supplemented by a brief description and exemplary verbs of visibility that indicate the corresponding cognitive process. Verbs of visibility should be used to formulate learning outcomes for the respective abilities, skills and competencies at the corresponding taxonomy level. Depending on the context, a verb of visibility can also be used at different taxonomy levels.

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.LearningOutcomeTaxonomy.AndersonAndKratwohl.Part1
data.value: The six taxonomy levels categorize the various cognitive processes that can come into play during learning. This classification describes different levels of complexity of the desired abilities, skills and competencies. The spectrum ranges from simple learning outcomes such as remembering facts to complex processes such as creating new ideas. The learning outcome taxonomy according to Anderson and Krathwohl comprises six taxonomy levels: Remembering, Understanding, Applying, Analyzing, Judging and Creating. Each of these levels represents a specific type of cognitive process. The structure of the taxonomy enables teachers to assign learning outcomes to a level of complexity and to take this into account when formulating the learning outcomes.

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.LearningOutcomeTaxonomy.AndersonAndKratwohl.Table.Col.One
data.value: Taxonomy level

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.LearningOutcomeTaxonomy.AndersonAndKratwohl.Table.Col.Two
data.value: Description

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.LearningOutcomeTaxonomy.AndersonAndKratwohl.Table.Col.Three
data.value: Example verbs

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.LearningOutcomeTaxonomy.AndersonAndKratwohl.Table.Col.One.Cell.One
data.value: Remember

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.LearningOutcomeTaxonomy.AndersonAndKratwohl.Table.Col.One.Cell.Two
data.value: Understand

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.LearningOutcomeTaxonomy.AndersonAndKratwohl.Table.Col.One.Cell.Three
data.value: Apply

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.LearningOutcomeTaxonomy.AndersonAndKratwohl.Table.Col.One.Cell.Four
data.value: Analyze

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.LearningOutcomeTaxonomy.AndersonAndKratwohl.Table.Col.One.Cell.Five
data.value: Evaluate

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.LearningOutcomeTaxonomy.AndersonAndKratwohl.Table.Col.One.Cell.Six
data.value: Create

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.LearningOutcomeTaxonomy.AndersonAndKratwohl.Table.Col.Two.Cell.One
data.value: Remembering is the ability to recall or repeat information without necessarily understanding it. This involves accessing relevant knowledge in long-term memory.

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.LearningOutcomeTaxonomy.AndersonAndKratwohl.Table.Col.Two.Cell.Two
data.value: Understanding is the ability to comprehend and interpret information (in oral, written or graphic form).

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.LearningOutcomeTaxonomy.AndersonAndKratwohl.Table.Col.Two.Cell.Three
data.value: Application can be defined as the ability to carry out or use a learned sequence of actions (a pattern, a method) in a specific situation.

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.LearningOutcomeTaxonomy.AndersonAndKratwohl.Table.Col.Two.Cell.Four
data.value: Analyzing can be described as the ability to break down learning content into its constructed elements and determine how these are connected/related to each other to form an overarching structure or purpose.

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.LearningOutcomeTaxonomy.AndersonAndKratwohl.Table.Col.Two.Cell.Five
data.value: Judging is the ability to evaluate the significance, quality or value of something based on criteria or standards.

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.LearningOutcomeTaxonomy.AndersonAndKratwohl.Table.Col.Two.Cell.Six
data.value: Creating is the ability to assemble elements into a coherent or functioning whole or to combine elements into a new pattern or structure.

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.LearningOutcomeTaxonomy.AndersonAndKratwohl.Table.Col.Three.Cell.One
data.value: enumerate, name, define, reproduce

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.LearningOutcomeTaxonomy.AndersonAndKratwohl.Table.Col.Three.Cell.Two
data.value: describe, represent, explain, summarize

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.LearningOutcomeTaxonomy.AndersonAndKratwohl.Table.Col.Three.Cell.Three
data.value: calculate, edit, operate, carry out

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.LearningOutcomeTaxonomy.AndersonAndKratwohl.Table.Col.Three.Cell.Four
data.value: select, test, compare, examine

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.LearningOutcomeTaxonomy.AndersonAndKratwohl.Table.Col.Three.Cell.Five
data.value: give reasons, decide, evaluate, classify

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.LearningOutcomeTaxonomy.AndersonAndKratwohl.Table.Col.Three.Cell.Six
data.value: design, develop, construct, assembling

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.LearningOutcomeTaxonomy.AndersonAndKratwohl.DescriptionText.Table
data.value: Table: Learning outcomes taxonomy according to Anderson and Krathwohl

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhatIsALearningOutcomeTaxonomy.RightSidebar.One
data.value: What is a learning outcomes taxonomy?

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhatIsALearningOutcomeTaxonomy.RightSidebar.Two
data.value: Learning outcome taxonomy according to Anderson & Krathwohl

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhatAreLearningOutcomes.RightSidebar.One
data.value: What are learning outcomes?

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.HowAreLearningOutcomesFormulated.Title
data.value: How are learning outcomes formulated?

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.HowAreLearningOutcomesFormulated.Info.Text
data.value: Learning outcomes describe what students should know and be able to do at the end of a learning stage or learning process and what attitudes are expected of them. Learning outcomes are therefore the most precise description possible of the intended learning outcomes. In practice, however, learning outcomes are rarely formulated in module handbooks or learning process descriptions; instead, they tend to be presented in a chapter structure that primarily describes the content.

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.HowAreLearningOutcomesFormulated.Part1
data.value: In order for learning outcomes to be effective in promoting learning, they must be formulated according to certain principles and communicated to students.

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.HowAreLearningOutcomesFormulated.Part2
data.value: Core elements for learning outcomes are a content-related and a process-related component:

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.HowAreLearningOutcomesFormulated.Part2.List1
data.value: The content component describes the subject-specific or interdisciplinary content to which the student's learning process relates.

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.HowAreLearningOutcomesFormulated.Part2.List2
data.value: The process component refers to an observable action that students are expected to perform. The reason for this is that the achievement of a learning outcome can only be recognized by an action of the student.

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.HowAreLearningOutcomesFormulated.Aspects
data.value: Reis (2013 ) lists five aspects that should be considered when formulating a learning outcome:

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.HowAreLearningOutcomesFormulated.Aspect.One.Title
data.value: Students' perspective:

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.HowAreLearningOutcomesFormulated.Aspect.Two.Title
data.value: Name specific activity:

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.HowAreLearningOutcomesFormulated.Aspect.Three.Title
data.value: Verb of visibility:

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.HowAreLearningOutcomesFormulated.Aspect.Four.Title
data.value: Verifiable standards:

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.HowAreLearningOutcomesFormulated.Aspect.Five.Title
data.value: Realistic requirements:

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.HowAreLearningOutcomesFormulated.Aspect.One
data.value: The learning outcomes must be formulated as a learning activity. It is not enough for the students to simply be the grammatical subject of the sentence. Phrases such as “The students get to know...” or “The students learn...” represent hidden teaching interventions because the activity lies with the teacher.

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.HowAreLearningOutcomesFormulated.Aspect.Two
data.value: The learning outcomes must be formulated as specifically as possible. The sequence of the required activity should be understandable from the outside. A clearly described action structure helps students to better understand the requirements so that they can orient themselves in the learning process.

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.HowAreLearningOutcomesFormulated.Aspect.Three
data.value: In order to be able to link the teaching interventions with the students' actions, “verbs of visibility” must be used in the formulation of the learning outcome. These are verbs that describe what the students should “do” with the learning content. Verbs such as “understand” or “recognize” are unsuitable as they do not make the performance of the action clear. Formulations such as “The students understand the basics of...” are not very helpful, as the question arises: What action is meant here? Similarly, only one verb should be used per learning outcome.

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.HowAreLearningOutcomesFormulated.Aspect.Four
data.value: A learning outcome should describe an action in such a way that it can be evaluated with clear criteria. If the declarative sentence is transformed into an imperative sentence, this should result in a clear examination task that describes what is to be done, with what and for what purpose. This aspect is important so that it is clear that the students can actually carry out the required action. In an examination, it is only possible to prove that students have understood something if they do something, e.g. reproduce a definition, apply a formula or analyze a case study. This point is important so that it is clear that students can actually perform the required action.

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.HowAreLearningOutcomesFormulated.Aspect.Five
data.value: In order for learning outcomes to have a guiding effect, they must not be formed solely according to the criterion of completeness. Each learning outcome is assigned a learning process that requires time for the necessary action steps. Too extensive or too many learning outcomes with too little time mean that the instructional components are increased. This leads to the learning activities being compensated for by teaching interventions.

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhatWherebyWhatFor.Title
data.value: The "what-whereby-what-for" structure

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhatWherebyWhatFor.Part1
data.value: In principle, the formulation of a learning outcome can be based on a systematic sentence structure: Subject, learning outcome (and context) and verb of visibility.

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhatWherebyWhatFor.Text.Image
data.value: The following example illustrates this:

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhatWherebyWhatFor.DescriptionText.Image
data.value: Figure: (1) subject, (2) learning outcome (and context), (3) verb of visibility

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhatWherebyWhatFor.Part3
data.value: Applying this structure to the above example of a learning outcome results in the following extension:

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhatWherebyWhatFor.Part2
data.value: The quality of a learning outcome can be further enhanced with the help of the “what-with-what-for” structure. A description can be found in the following table:

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhatWherebyWhatFor.DescriptionText.Table
data.value: Table: What-whereby-what-for structure

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhatWherebyWhatFor.Table.Col.One
data.value: Structure

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhatWherebyWhatFor.Table.Col.Two
data.value: Description

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhatWherebyWhatFor.Table.Col.Three
data.value: Key questions

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhatWherebyWhatFor.Table.Col.One.Cell.One
data.value: What?

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhatWherebyWhatFor.Table.Col.One.Cell.Two
data.value: Whereby?

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhatWherebyWhatFor.Table.Col.One.Cell.Three
data.value: What for?

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhatWherebyWhatFor.Table.Col.Two.Cell.One
data.value: The “what” indicates which learning content (content-related topic) is addressed as part of the students' acquisition of skills. In conjunction with a verb of visibility and the corresponding taxonomy level, it describes an ability, skill or competence that students should have developed at the end of the learning process. The “what” corresponds to the above-mentioned systematic sentence structure of a learning outcome.

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhatWherebyWhatFor.Table.Col.Two.Cell.Two
data.value: The “whereby” describes the theoretical or practical tools students use to carry out their actions. These are, for example, formulas, models, plans, concepts, tools, etc., which are taught during the course and whose application is practiced. The use and linking of these tools forms the basis for competent action.

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhatWherebyWhatFor.Table.Col.Two.Cell.Three
data.value: The “What for” provides an outlook on the purpose for which the learning unit was designed. The focus is not on the exam. Rather, the “What for” illustrates the students' options for action once they have mastered what they have learned. Often the action or situation of the “what for” takes place in a more complex environment and under more difficult conditions than in the learning situation. The “what for” does not refer to the examination.

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhatWherebyWhatFor.Table.Col.Three.Cell.One
data.value: What exactly can students do at the end of the course?

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhatWherebyWhatFor.Table.Col.Three.Cell.Two
data.value: How do students achieve the ability, skill or competence?

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhatWherebyWhatFor.Table.Col.Three.Cell.Three
data.value: What “tools” do students use to exercise the competencies?

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhatWherebyWhatFor.Table.Col.Three.Cell.Four
data.value: For what (specific and/or long-term) purpose should the skills be acquired?

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhatWherebyWhatFor.Table.Col.Three.Cell.Five
data.value: What do students need the acquired skills, abilities or competencies for after the course?

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhatWherebyWhatFor.Table.Col.Two.Example.What
data.value: Students will be able to identify the different genera of the bird of prey species “eagle” on the basis of their plumage

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhatWherebyWhatFor.Table.Col.Two.Example.Whereby
data.value: ... by accurately classifying the coloring of the individual feathers with the aid of specialist literature

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.WhatWherebyWhatFor.Table.Col.Two.Example.WhatFor
data.value: ... to correctly categorize eagles living in the wild during a bird excursion.

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.HowAreLearningOutcomesFormulated.RightSidebar.One
data.value: How are learning outcomes formulated?

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.HowAreLearningOutcomesFormulated.RightSidebar.Two
data.value: What-whereby-what-for structure

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.QualitycheckForLearningOutcomes.Title
data.value: Quality check for the formulation of learning outcomes

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.QualitycheckForLearningOutcomes.Text
data.value: The following quality check for high-quality formulated learning outcomes serves as a working aid. Answering the reflection questions is helpful for a final critical analysis of the formulated learning outcomes.

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.HowAreLearningOutcomesFormulated.RightSidebar.Three
data.value: Quality check

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.QualityCheck.DescriptionText.Table
data.value: Table: Quality check for learning outcomes

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.QualityCheck.Table.Col.One
data.value: No.

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.QualityCheck.Table.Col.Two
data.value: Category

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.QualityCheck.Table.Col.Three
data.value: Reflection question

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.QualityCheck.Table.Col.Two.Cell.One
data.value: Learning outcomes formulated as learning activities

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.QualityCheck.Table.Col.Two.Cell.Two
data.value: Concrete activity

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.QualityCheck.Table.Col.Two.Cell.Three
data.value: Verbs of visibility

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.QualityCheck.Table.Col.Two.Cell.Four
data.value: Verifiable standards

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.QualityCheck.Table.Col.Two.Cell.Five
data.value: Realistic requirements

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.QualityCheck.Table.Col.Two.Cell.Six
data.value: Theoretical / practical tools

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.QualityCheck.Table.Col.Two.Cell.Seven
data.value: Outlook on meaning and purpose

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.QualityCheck.Table.Col.Three.Cell.One
data.value: Wer ist der/die wirkliche Akteur:in der Handlung?

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.QualityCheck.Table.Col.Three.Cell.Two
data.value: Is the course of the activity comprehensible to outsiders?

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.QualityCheck.Table.Col.Three.Cell.Three
data.value: Do the verbs describe an action on/with an external learning object

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.QualityCheck.Table.Col.Three.Cell.Four
data.value: Can an examination assignment be formulated from the sentence?

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.QualityCheck.Table.Col.Three.Cell.Five
data.value: Is the amount of work involved in the learning process proportionate?

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.QualityCheck.Table.Col.Three.Cell.Six
data.value: Are the theoretical or practical tools for the action named?

data.name: CreateStructuredLearningOutcome.QualityCheck.Table.Col.Three.Cell.Seven
data.value: Is it clear what purpose the learning unit serves?
